node.title: Inditex, a Spanish fashion giant, will be led by Marta Ortega, the founder’s daughter.
node.alt: Marta Ortega and her father, Amancio Ortega, in 2016. Ms. Ortega, who has worked at Inditex for 11 years, was named the company’s chairwoman.
node.description: Ms. Ortega, 37, will become chairwoman in a generational handoff as the global fashion retailer faces supply chain issues.
node.content: ["Inditex, the giant Spanish fashion retailer, has appointed Marta Ortega, daughter of the company\u2019s co-founder, as its chairwoman, unexpectedly fast-tracking a generational handover at a time when the fashion sector is facing important supply chain challenges linked to the pandemic, the company said on Tuesday.", "Ms. Ortega, 37, will take over in April from Pablo Isla, who has led the company since 2011 and has been widely credited with steering the group\u2019s online and international growth, including into the Chinese market. Inditex sells brands that include Zara, Massimo Dutti, Bershka and Pull & Bear.", "Ms. Ortega has spent the past 15 years working for her family\u2019s company, starting as an assistant at Bershka.", "\u201cI have always said that I would dedicate my life to building upon my parents\u2019 legacy, looking to the future but learning from the past,\u201d she said in a statement.", "Inditex also appointed a new chief executive, \u00d3scar Garc\u00eda Maceiras, a former state attorney who joined Inditex in March. The current chief executive, Carlos Crespo, is switching back to his former job, chief operating officer.", "Ms. Ortega had long been considered in line to take over from her father, Amancio Ortega, 85, who is regarded as Spain\u2019s richest man and is the majority shareholder in the company.", "Inditex shares tumbled more than 5 percent on Tuesday after the appointment was announced. Investors were concerned that the new team of Ms. Ortega and Mr. Garc\u00eda Maceiras lacked operational experience at a time when retailers have been struggling with the coronavirus pandemic, as well as its resulting supply bottlenecks.", "The share price, however, rebounded on Wednesday, gaining 4.5 percent.", "\u201cThe timing is not the best,\u201d Kepler, a brokerage, wrote in a note to investors. \u201cWe believe that both Marta Ortega and the C.E.O. \u00d3scar Maceiras have a lot to prove when it comes to their ability to run this big monster in the middle of the Covid crisis.\u201d", "Inditex was founded by Mr. Ortega and his then-wife, Rosal\u00eda Mera, in 1975 in Galicia, in northwestern Spain, where Inditex still makes some of its clothing. The company also produces in other parts of Europe, Asia and Africa, and has more than 6,000 stores worldwide. "]
